Text: Komikan:  It is known by the Aymaras, a neighboring ethnolinguistic group to the Quechuan people, as kumisiña.

<Text: Komikan:  J. I. Molina, in 1787, described it as ‘"el artificioso juego del ajedrez, al cual dan el nombre de comican"’ which translates to ""the ingenious game of chess to which they (the Mapuche) give the name comican"’.>
Triplets:<J. I. Molina
9:
--------------------
Text: Komikan:  in 1898, Stewart Culin, the famed anthropologist, named a game played in Peru as Solitario.
Triplets:<Stewart Culin
11:
--------------------
<Text: Komikan:  The game may also be known in Peru as Kukuli.>
Triplets:<Komikan

 Komikan:<Komikan
14:
--------------------
Text: Komikan:  In Komikan, one player has only a single piece, usually called a "puma" or "jaguar", or ""kom ikelu"" (in Mapuche language "the one which eats all"), or "leon" (Spanish for lion), which can move one space at a time or capture the other player's pieces by hopping over them.
Triplets:<Komikan
